{{short description|Jamaican-born English serial killer}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Theodore Johnson | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = 1954 | birth_place = [[Jamaica]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = 26 years imprisonment | victims = 3 | beginyear = 1981 | endyear = 2016 | country = [[England]] | states = [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]], [[London]] | apprehended = '''For the final time on''' 15 December 2016 | imprisoned = }} '''Theodore Johnson''' (born 1954) is a [[Jamaica]]n-born [[England|English]] [[serial killer]] who murdered his three wives/girlfriends over a span of four decades. After the murder of his last victim, Angela Best, he was sentenced to 26 years imprisonment.<ref name=wife>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/theodore-johnson-serial-wife-killer-26-years-murdering-third-partner-angela-best-old-bailey-courts-a8144176.html|title=Theodore Johnson: Serial wife killer jailed for 26 years after murdering third partner|author=Lucy Pasha-Robinson|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=5 January 2018}}</ref><ref name=merciless>{{Citeweb|url=https://news.sky.com/story/serial-killer-theodore-johnson-jailed-for-26-years-11196527|title=Triple killer Theodore Johnson jailed for 'merciless' attack on ex-girlfriend|publisher=[[Sky News]]|date=5 January 2018}}</ref>
==Biography== Johnson was born in Jamaica as one of 11 children, working on a banana plantation.<ref name=kill>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jan/05/man-theodore-johnson-on-conditional-release-who-killed-partner-lied-to-authorities-about-relationship|title=Killer on conditional release who murdered partner given life sentence|author=Jamie Grierson|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=5 January 2018}}</ref> He moved to the [[United Kingdom]] in 1980 with his wife Yvonne, and started working at a car repair service centre shortly before killing his first wife.<ref name=wife/>
===Murder of Yvonne Johnson=== In 1981, an argument began between Johnson and Yvonne after she wouldn't let him go to church for being "not dressed well enough".<ref name=jail>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-42583114|title=Triple killer Theodore Johnson jailed for 26 years|work=[[BBC News]]|date=5 January 2018}}</ref> Johnson then proceeded to hit Yvonne over the head with a vase, before pushing her out off the balcony from the couple's ninth-floor [[Wolverhampton]] home.<ref name=merciless/><ref name=jail/> When brought to trial in [[Staffordshire]], the judge described him as a "battered husband" who had suffered abuse from his wife, sentencing him only for [[manslaughter]] for the "provocated" murder.<ref name=wife/>
===Murder of Yvonne Bennett=== Eleven years after killing his first wife, Johnson was released from prison, and soon met Yvonne Bennett in Wolverhampton. The couple moved to [[Finsbury Park (area)|Finsbury Park]] in north [[London]] together, with Yvonne giving birth to a daughter, but separated after Johnson discovered that she was having an affair. He began stalking Yvonne, and at one point had to be removed from the house by police days before her death. In 1993, while their 2-year-old daughter was sleeping, Johnson strangled Bennett with a belt at their home.<ref name=wife/><ref name=merciless/> He then phoned the police to confess his crime and unsuccessfully tried to hang himself from a tree before giving himself up to authorities.<ref name=jail/>
At his trial at the [[Old Bailey]], it was claimed that he suffered from depression and a personality disorder. He pled guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. He was found guilty and sent to a mental institution.<ref name=wife/><ref name=merciless/>
===Meeting Best=== In September 1994, Johnson was allowed out of the psychiatric ward for the first time on escorted [[parole]], and in mid-1995, he was allowed to spend two days at a [[City and Guilds of London Institute|City and Guilds]] course on furniture restoration by himself. There, he met 51-year-old mother-of-four Angela Best, who had moved to [[Tottenham]] from [[Manchester]], and they quickly began a relationship. Johnson was released by a mental health tribunal in October 1997, on condition that he notified the supervising doctors and social workers about any relationship with women he formed. However, he did not reveal his relationship with Best until shortly before her death.<ref name=merciless/> During a visit by authorities to his [[Dartmouth Park]] home, a wood carving spelling out "Love" was found on Johnson's mantelpiece, but the object did not arouse any suspicion.<ref name=wife/><ref name=kill/>
In September 2016, the couple split up after Angela found out about Johnson's previous convictions in a detailed letter,<ref name=kill/> with Best saying that she had felt the "happiest" she had ever been after finding love with someone else, despite Johnson continuing to profess his undying love for her daily.<ref name=wife/> When he was visited by a social worker and psychiatrist on 8 December 2016, he was not found to be in a depressive state and still denied being in a relationship. Two days before Best's murder, he had another appointment, but it was called off because his social worker was sick.<ref name=wife/>
===Murder of Angela Best=== On the morning of 15 December Ms. Best decided to visit Johnson at his [[Islington]] flat to help with an appointment with the Jamaican embassy. Soon after entering the house, Best was struck at least six times with a claw hammer by Johnson, who finally strangled her with a dressing gown cord despite her efforts to defend herself. Hours after killing her, Johnson proceeded to throw himself in front of an express train at [[Cheshunt railway station]], losing his right arm and left hand in the process.<ref name=wife/><ref name=jail/> While the medics were treating his injuries, authorities visited his home and discovered Best's body in the living room.<ref name=merciless/>
==Trial and sentence== At trial, the now-wheelchair bound Johnson confessed to killing Angela Best, and was sentenced to 26 years imprisonment. His lawyer, Annette Henry QC, said that he would likely die behind bars and that: "He does not wish to be alive. He hates himself for what happened."<ref name=wife/> The crown later appealed and Johnson's sentence was increased from a minimum of 26 years to a minimum of 30.{{Citation needed|date=August 2019}}
Best's family, among them her son Raphael and her sisters Lorraine Jones and Valerie Archibold, described her loss as "immeasureable", adding that she loved her children and grandchildren dearly.<ref name=wife/><ref name=merciless/>
Camden and Islington NHS Trust, which was responsible for Johnson’s care in the community since 2004, said it would provide Best’s family with an independent report and that Johnson’s treatment complied with conditions set by the Mental Health Tribunal which oversaw his discharge in 1997.<ref name=wife/>
